and local officials that targeted gun violence. The strategy entailed
[prosecution](/wiki/Prosecution "Prosecution") of gun violations in Federal
courts, where [sentencing guidelines](/wiki/Sentencing_guidelines "Sentencing
guidelines") were tougher. Project Exile also involved outreach and education
efforts through media campaigns, getting the message out about the
crackdown.[244] Research analysts offered different opinions as to the
program's success in reducing gun crime. Authors of a 2003 analysis of the
program argued that the decline in gun homicide was part of a "general
regression to the mean" across U.S. cities with high homicide rates.[245]
Authors of a 2005 study disagreed, concluding that Richmond's gun homicide
rate fell more rapidly than the rates in other large U.S. cities with other
influences controlled.[244][246]

### Project Safe
Neighborhoods[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_violence_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Project Safe Neighborhoods")]

[Project Safe Neighborhoods](/wiki/Project_Safe_Neighborhoods "Project Safe
Neighborhoods") (PSN) is a national strategy for reducing gun violence that
builds on the strategies implemented in Operation Ceasefire and [Project
Exile](/wiki/Project_Exile "Project Exile").[247] PSN was established in 2001,
with support from the [Bush
administration](/wiki/George_W._Bush_administration "George W. Bush
administration"), channelled through the [United States Attorney's
Offices](/wiki/United_States_Attorney "United States Attorney") in the [United
States Department of Justice](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice
"United States Department of Justice"). The [Federal
government](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government
of the United States") has spent over [US$](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United
States dollar")1.5 billion since the program's inception on the hiring of
[prosecutors](/wiki/Prosecutor "Prosecutor"), and providing assistance to
state and local jurisdictions in support of training and community outreach
efforts.[248][249]

### Americans for Responsible
Solutions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_violence_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Americans for Responsible Solutions")]

Main article: [Americans for Responsible
Solutions](/wiki/Americans_for_Responsible_Solutions "Americans for
Responsible Solutions")

Americans for Responsible Solutions was started in January 2013 as a [not-for-
profit organization](/wiki/Nonprofit_organization "Nonprofit organization")
whose mission is to "encourage elected officials to stand up for solutions to
prevent gun violence and protect responsible gun ownership by communicating
directly with the constituents that elect them."[250] The organization was
announced on January 8, 2013 by [Gabrielle "Gabby"
Giffords](/wiki/Gabrielle_Giffords "Gabrielle Giffords"), a former
[Democratic](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party
\(United States\)") member of the [United States House of
Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States
House of Representatives") for [Arizona's 8th congressional
district](/wiki/Arizona%27s_8th_congressional_district "Arizona's 8th
congressional district"), and [Mark Kelly](/wiki/Mark_Kelly "Mark Kelly"), a
retired American [astronaut](/wiki/Astronaut "Astronaut").[251] In an [op-
ed](/wiki/Op-ed "Op-ed") published in [USA Today](/wiki/USA_Today "USA
Today"), Gifford and Kelly referred to the
[NRA](/wiki/National_Rifle_Association "National Rifle Association") lobby and
sought to counter it by creating a lobby dedicated to responsible [gun
control](/wiki/Gun_control "Gun control") measures.[252]

## Research
limitations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_violence_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: Research limitations")]

In the United States, [research](/wiki/Research "Research") into firearms and
violent crime is fraught with difficulties, associated with limited
[data](/wiki/Data "Data") on gun ownership and use,[37] firearms markets, and
aggregation of crime data.[1] Research studies into gun violence have
primarily taken one of two approaches: [case-control](/wiki/Case-control
"Case-control") studies and [social
ecology](/wiki/Social_ecology_\(academic_field\) "Social ecology \(academic
field\)").[1] Gun ownership is usually determined through
[surveys](/wiki/Statistical_survey "Statistical survey"),
[proxy](/wiki/Proxy_\(statistics\) "Proxy \(statistics\)") variables, and
sometimes with [production](/wiki/Mass_production "Mass production") and
[import](/wiki/Import "Import") figures. In statistical analysis of homicides
and other types of crime which are rare events, these data tend to have
[poisson distributions](/wiki/Poisson_distribution "Poisson distribution"),
which also presents methodological challenges to researchers. With data
aggregation, it is difficult to make inferences about individual
behavior.[253] This problem, known as [ecological
fallacy](/wiki/Ecological_fallacy "Ecological fallacy"), is not always handled
properly by researchers; this leads some to jump to conclusions that their
data do not necessarily support.[254]

In 1996 the NRA lobbied Congressman [Jay Dickey](/wiki/Jay_Dickey "Jay
Dickey") (R-Ark.) to include budget provisions that prohibited the Centers for
Disease Control (CDC) from advocating or promoting gun control and that
deleted $2.6 million from the CDC budget, the exact amount the CDC had spent
on firearms research the previous year. The ban was later extended to all
research funded by the [Department of Health and Human
Services](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Health_and_Human_Services "United
States Department of Health and Human Services") (DHHS). According to an
article in [Nature](/wiki/Nature_\(journal\) "Nature \(journal\)"), this made
gun research more difficult, reduced the number of studies, and discouraged
researchers from even talking about gun violence at medical and scientific
conferences. In 2013, after the December 2012 [Sandy Hook Elementary School
shooting](/wiki/Sandy_Hook_Elementary_School_shooting "Sandy Hook Elementary
School shooting"), President [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama")
ordered the CDC to resume funding research on gun violence and prevention, and
put $10 million in the 2014 budget request for it.[255] Prior to this, U.S.
public funding directed towards gun violence prevention was less than $2
million annually, a disproportionately low total compared to public funding
totals for other leading public health burdens with respect to potential years
of life lost.[256]

qa.question: number of gun deaths in the united states
qa.answer: ['In 2013, there were 73,505 nonfatal firearm injuries (23.2 injuries per 100,000 U.S. citizens),[2][3] and 33,636 deaths due to "injury by firearms"']
